content.description: This route starts the same as for Timber, but once on the face, traverses out left on a dike system across the face and ends at the left edge of the summit.
content.protection: Slings for the tree branches at the start, then quick draws for the rest of the climb. Rap anchor on top.

content.description: This cool climb is a novel experience.  The route starts by climbing a large pine tree, actually quite aways up the branches, until one can hop on the face of this very large boulder at a lump/knob. Face climb up the face past to few bolts to the summit and a set of anchors.
content.protection: Slings to tie off a few of the tree branches, and then quick draws for a few bolts.  Bolted rap anchor on top.
content.location: This climb is located not on Thrutcher Dome , but in the secluded , and difficult to reach Valley behind the N. Face of Thrutcher Dome.  It is best approached to hike way N. up the main wonderland wash, then then hike in past Wheel of Fortune (N. Face of Disneyland), past Monument Manor Crag, then scramble up boulders and into the Valley behind Thrutcher Dome.  Maybe see what Vogel has to say in his guide and directions to the 2 established climbs already there and in his book  (Ground Ron and Feeding Frenzy).

climbs.name: Thrutcher
climbs.fa: Dave Evans and Mike Lechlinski, March 1978

content.description:
Climb up and behind a giant flake leaning against the main face that forms a squeeze chimney. Reasonably protected but as the name indicates a little awkward.

Descend from bolted anchor atop the route.
content.location:
Left of

Invasion of My Fantasy

on the west face.

climbs.name: No Glove, No Love
climbs.fa: Frazier Haney, Todd Gordon, Tucker Tech

content.description: On Middle tower, right of Disneyland Dome between Life without Principle and Whales on Ice. 2 bolts supplement lots of trad protection.
content.protection: Trad Rack, mostly med to large.
content.location: Right of Disneyland Dome, between Life without Principle and Whales on Ice.

content.description:
Begin at the southern end of a light brown crag adjacent to the highest and northern most crag. Climb in a left tending direction past the 3rd bolt until reaching a horizontal at the 6th bolt. Continue up and slightly right past three more bolts to the summit. You will be greeted by 10+ / 11- moves above each bolt enroute to the top. The most difficult moves occur between the 2nd and 3rd bolt.

The coarseness of the rock promotes astonishingly good friction if you trust smearing on the tiny protruding granules. Three or four stars out of five.
content.protection: Quickdraws for nine bolts (3/8") and an optional #1 or #2 camalot between the 6th and 7th bolts. A two bolt anchor with rings is on top.

content.description:
Up and into the wide crack/chimney. A little physical but secure and reasonably well protected.

Descend from bolted anchors atop

Thrutcher

.
content.location: The obvious wide crack splitting the formation's west face.

content.description: On the lower left side of the face, there are two obvious cracks.  This is the left one.  The crux is about 15 feet up at an overhang.  A hand crack quickly widens to a tricky V-slot.  This route is not very sustained or noteworthy.
content.location: This is on the north face of Thrutcher Dome.  Approach from the east.

climbs.name: Feeding Frenzy
climbs.fa: Don Wilson and Jack Marshall, November 1988

content.description: This is a steep finger and hand crack, a fairly nice route.
content.location: This is the right of two cracks on the north face.
